title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
text:
Ongoing Research


 
Who Locates Where

Classical Urban question
Want to apply that in several domains:








1. Parents


Where do parents have children?









2. Family Networks


How does the family network affect location choices?









3. Bus Operators


How do firms locate in space to avoid competition?

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
section: Fertility, Housing Costs and City Growth
text:
Fertility, Housing Costs and City Growth

There are relatively few children in the center of cities.
Across cities, smaller cities have more children.
In general, there is negative density dependence of fertility across French Urban Areas.

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
text:
Problem: Joint Decision
Econometrically, thatâ€™s a mess: People choose location and fertility at the same time. And if not, highly interdependent.


Either need an exogenous shock to location or fertility:
Forced location (choices)?
Policies randomly affecting fertility?



Or a credible model.


Check it out!

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
text:
Family Networks

A lot of work (urban and labor) has considered why people move.



The role of moving costs is first order. One Example. ğŸ˜¬




Surprisingly litte is known about the role of an individualâ€™s family network in this setting.




What is the value of having a family member in a city? Like a person-specific amenity.

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
section: Family Networks: Why Do We Care
text:
Family Networks: Why Do We Care

State of the Art models like Adda, Dustmann + GÃ¶rlach still need to model other unobserved factors affecting location preference in a random fashion.



How much randomness is left in this model once we account for family network?




Policy: Should we distribute vouchers to people considering moving back to their elderly parents?



Status: early stage, stylized facts, model that runs, lots of parallel computation, threading and multicore.


Not sure itâ€™s the right model.

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
text:
Dead Miles





We find: 13% of London bus drive times are dead
Empirically relevant for bidding behaviour.

title: ScPo M1 Research Project Presentation
text:
What about a central Dispatcher?






Central planner who decides who has to park bus where.
Observing all operational constraints.
Reduces dead miles by 14%.
